data.title: Latest releases not on GitHub
data.body: Not sure if this is intentional or not, but we're currently at [release 0.10.9](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates#vscode). However, the [releases page](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases) here on GitHub only shows up to 0.10.6.

data.title: Snippet support for tasks.json
data.body:
### Details

Instead of generating a tasks.json with a lot of well know tasks.json examples we now present the user a list of snippets to choose from. To test do the following:
- new workspace
- F1 > Task Configure > Enter

Expected: the editor opens and it looks like this:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1931590/13424945/084d5a44-dfa4-11e5-94db-20749b95792f.png)

You can pick a snippet and it gets correctly inserted into the task.json

Add a trace commandline option that logs actions on the file system

data.body: Issue #508 is open since a long time and we have no good handle on what work load triggers the crash. In the bugs users have offered to send us log information, but we currently do have such a log and we should start to implement one. Initially we can log file open/close.

data.title: nls support for package.json and common-js
data.body:
### Assignments
- [x] Windows @joaomoreno 
- [x] OS X @weinand  
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 
### Details

We now have nls support for package.json and common-js. To test do the following:
#### Package.json for Extensions
- create a package.nls.json file as a sibling to your package.json file
- in `package.json`, replace strings that should be localized with a key surrounded by %%. For example

``` json
"commands": [
            {
                "command": "typescript.reloadProjects",
                "title": "%typescript.reloadProjects.title%",
                "category": "TypeScript"
            }
        ],
```
- In the package.nls.json add a key value pair that maps the key to a human readable value for our default language (which is English).

``` json
{
    "typescript.reloadProjects.title": "Reload Project",
}
```

Ensure that when you start  the extension the correct string is presented in the user interface. Also ensure that pseudo translation works. To do so start vscode with --locale=pseudo. The strings from the package.nls.json should be enclosed in [] and vowels should be doubled.
#### CommonJS Extensions

Install `vscode-nls` as a dependency of your extension. In the extension main add the following code:

``` typescript
import * as nls from 'vscode-nls';
let localize = nls.config({ locale: 'pseudo' })();
```

And in the activate function add

``` typescript
console.log(localize('key', 'Extension activated'));
```

This should show the following in the console:

```
[Plugin Host] Exteensiioon aactiivaateed
```

In other files in the extension you don't need to configure the nls module again. You can simple do:

``` typescript
import * as nls from 'vscode-nls';
let localize = nls.loadMessageBundle();
```

If you want to leave the code in since you tested it with your extension code then simply remove the locale property and initialize as follows:

``` typescript
import * as nls from 'vscode-nls';
let localize = nls.config()();
```

data.title: File with @ character not visible in explorer tab
data.body:
I've got images for retina screens named 'discovery@2x.png'. It's both visible and accessible in Explorer:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1797855/13169581/9f06e558-d721-11e5-9a31-82caff14c94c.png)

But not visible in VSCode Explorer tab:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1797855/13169595/b9ea5ada-d721-11e5-948c-2c05f9999e63.png)

My "settings.json" lies below. I believe '@2x.png' file doesn't match any of those rules:

```
{
    "files.exclude": {
        "**/.git": true,
        "**/.DS_Store": true,
        "**/.vscode": false,
        "**/node_modules": true,
        "**/destination": true,
        "**/.gitignore": true,
        "**/.cache": true,
        "**/.tmp": true
    }
}
```

data.title: LanguageClient does not handle IntelliSense correctly for PowerShell static class methods
data.body:
_From @daviwil on February 18, 2016 18:53_

We're seeing an issue in the PowerShell extension where our trigger for static .NET class methods is not resulting in the right IntelliSense in VS Code.  To reproduce the issue, try typing this in a PowerShell script file after installing the PowerShell extension on a Windows machine:

``` powershell
[DateTime]::
```

After the second `:` we would expect an IntelliSense pane to appear.  Our language server sends the `:` character back as a triggerCharacter in our completionProvider section of the serverCapabilities object in the Initialize response.  Could there be an issue with the double-colon?

Another interesting problem here is that using `Ctrl+Space` after the double-colon results in an empty IntelliSense list even though our server gets the request correctly and returns a list of IntelliSense results.  Can you think of a reason why the results wouldn't be applied in this case?

We're tracking the issue on our side here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellEditorServices/issues/163

Let me know if it's more appropriate to file this on the Microsoft/vscode repo.

Thanks!

cc @rkeithhill @dfinke

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node#26_

data.title: Fix opening code via command line using relative paths
data.body:
Opening code using `code ..`, `code ../..`  was opening the wrong directory
since trailing '.' characters were being trimmed by the launch code.

Fixes #3127 

---

@bpasero I'm assuming that the trimming was added for Windows, just wanted to make sure that was the intent. Or can we remove it?

data.title: Add "launch"-type config to launch.json
data.body: Now I can just hit F5 to build and debug vscode. Also removed 'outDir' which isn't used anymore.

data.title: Cannot invoke an expression whose type lacks a call signature. (Angularjs syntax)
data.body:
VSCode gives a "syntax error" to this Angularjs code:

`var myarrayFiltered = $filter('filterName')(myarray, param);`
or 
`var myarrayFiltered = $filter('filterName')(myarray, param1, param2);`

VScode "syntax error" detail:

> Cannot invoke an expression whose type lacks a call signature.
> Usage: $filter(name);
> (parameter) $filter: ng.IFilterService<{}>(name: string) => {} (+9 overloads)

This kind of errors prevent me from using VSCode as my main editor. Is there an option to turn off "_cannot invoke ..._ " "errors"?

data.title: Extensions can't work with large files
data.body:
VS Code doesn't provide the document element of the editor when a large file is open. This means that extensions can't get any file information at all.

Editing still works fine, even a (large number of) find/replace functions work.

Using `registerTextEditorCommand` fails to enter the callback function at all (presumably the exception is thrown when the arguments to the callback are created) and trying to access the document via the activeTextEditor in `registerCommand` fails (throws) when attempting to access the `.document` getter of the `TextEditor` object. Inspecting the activeTextEditor object shows that `_documentData` is `undefined`

I've had this failure with a 6MB file. Yet editing, and highlighting (JSON) work on a 16MB file.

data.title: Debugging with Mocha and TypeScript does not reach breakpoints
data.body:
I am using `Mocha` to run tests due to it's popularity yet I cannot get the debugger to attach when launching a task to run tests.

What I have started to do is run tests using Grunt with the `debug-brk` option set to true so that it stops on the first statement and waits for a debugger to connect on port 5858. I can then attach the VS Code debugger and start using breakpoints.

I just discovered that when I attach the debugger in this way I need to make sure that `sourceMaps` is set to true. By default this option is not even defined with the "Attach" task. This is an important detail. I hope including it here helps others who are working with TypeScript. It would be helpful to add it to the tasks template even with the value set to off like it is for launching tasks.

I am creating this issue in hopes of learning how I can get VS Code to automatically attach to the running Mocha task with it working with source maps so I can debug through TypeScript without the extra step.

``` json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch Tests",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": ["--reporter", "spec", "--timeout", "5000", "--require", "source-map-support/register", "test/**/*.js"],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "dev"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/test/" 
        },
        {
            "name": "Launch Tests (debug)",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": ["--reporter", "spec", "--timeout", "5000", "--debug", "--require", "source-map-support/register", "test/**/*.js"],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "dev"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/test/" 
        }
        {
            "name": "Attach (5858)",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "sourceMaps": true
        },
    ]
}
```

data.title: "Open Recent" doesn't remember the most recent items

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It seems that when "Open Recent" fills up, it doesn't expunge the oldest item and move everything else down the list in favor of the newest item at the top. This same behavior applies equally to recent folders and recent files. 

This is on Windows 7.

data.title: Add action for "Switch to Editor View"
data.body:
![switchtoeditor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6125444/13159282/3486d2f0-d691-11e5-93a2-7e59e3eedd58.png)

The "Switch to Changes View" button in the top right of an editor has the command `workbench.git.action.globalOpenChange`, but the corresponding "Switch to Editor View" button has no command. Well it looks like it might be `workbench.git.action.openInEditor` but that isn't made public or something because trying to execute it doesn't work, and I can't find anything in the list of commands.

I'd like them both to have commands so I can switch back & forth between changes and editor view with keyboard shortcuts.
